Figurative Meaning: Cooperation and mutual support in a relationship
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: They support each other through thick and thin
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Malay metaphor drawn from nature; aur (bamboo) and tebing (riverbank) coexist in harmony
First Example Sentence: Pasangan itu hidup bagai aur dengan tebing, saling membantu tanpa mengira susah atau senang.
Second Example Sentence: Dalam pasukan ini, kita harus bekerja bagai aur dengan tebing.
Third Example Sentence: Nilai persahabatan mereka jelas, ibarat aur dengan tebing dalam semua hal.

Figurative Meaning: Doing something half-heartedly or without genuine effort
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: To do something superficially or carelessly
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to someone coughing on the staircase and not entering the house—symbolizing minimal effort
First Example Sentence: Jangan buat kerja macam melepaskan batuk di tangga sahaja.
Second Example Sentence: Laporan yang disiapkan itu nampak seperti melepaskan batuk di tangga.
Third Example Sentence: Kalau sekadar melepaskan batuk di tangga, lebih baik jangan buat langsung.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Simile; fixed clause with verb phrase
Figurative Meaning: To care for something/someone very delicately and attentively
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: To treat someone with utmost care
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to the delicate act of carrying oil without spilling; symbolizes extreme care
First Example Sentence: Ibu bapa itu menjaga anaknya bagai menatang minyak yang penuh.
Second Example Sentence: Gurunya memelihara setiap pelajar seperti menatang minyak yang penuh.
Third Example Sentence: Dia membela reputasinya bagai menatang minyak yang penuh.

Idiom (Malaysian Malay): bagai enau dalam belukar, melepaskan pucuk masing-masing
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Complex clause; simile and embedded clause
Figurative Meaning: Each person acts selfishly, without considering the group
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Everyone is only looking out for their own interests
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Enau (a wild palm) grows in clusters, but each shoot reaches independently
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Malaysian M: /baɡai ɛnau dala̠m bəlu̯kaʁ məlepaskan putʃuʔ masing-masing/
First Example Sentence: Mesyuarat itu tidak mencapai kata sepakat, bagai enau dalam belukar, melepaskan pucuk masing-masing.
Second Example Sentence: Projek ini gagal kerana semua ahli bertindak bagai enau dalam belukar.
Third Example Sentence: Sikap bagai enau dalam belukar tidak sesuai dalam kerja berkumpulan.

Figurative Meaning: In a very precarious or dangerous situation
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: In a risky and fragile position
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Describes an egg balanced on a horn—unstable and likely to fall
First Example Sentence: Keadaan ekonomi negara kini bagai telur di hujung tanduk.
Second Example Sentence: Dia hidup dalam ketakutan, bagai telur di hujung tanduk.
Third Example Sentence: Hubungan mereka rapuh, bagai telur di hujung tanduk.

Figurative Meaning: Small efforts accumulate into something significant
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Small contributions will add up over time
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional advice emphasizing frugality and patience
First Example Sentence: Simpanlah duit walaupun sedikit, sikit-sikit lama-lama jadi bukit.
Second Example Sentence: Dia mengulang hafalan setiap hari—sikit-sikit lama-lama jadi bukit.
Third Example Sentence: Usaha kecil ini bukan sia-sia, sikit-sikit lama-lama jadi bukit.

Figurative Meaning: Trying to fix something and making it worse
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Making things worse while trying to help
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to a mouse supposedly fixing a gourd—actually ruining it
First Example Sentence: Dia cuba membetulkan mesin itu, tapi jadi bagai tikus membaiki labu.
Second Example Sentence: Jangan sentuh kod itu kalau tak faham—nanti bagai tikus membaiki labu.
Third Example Sentence: Bantuan yang diberinya lebih merosakkan, macam tikus membaiki labu.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Pegar is a bird once thought to protect rice fields—but instead eats the rice
First Example Sentence: Pengurus itu disiasat—harapkan pegar, pegar makan padi.
Second Example Sentence: Dia ditugaskan menjaga anak, tapi harapkan pegar, pegar makan padi.
Third Example Sentence: Harapkan pegawai jujur, rupanya pegar makan padi.

Figurative Meaning: Helping someone ungrateful who later harms you
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Helping someone who later turns against you
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: A metaphor suggesting the risk of helping someone dangerous or resentful
First Example Sentence: Dia sanggup tolong, tapi akhirnya bagai melepaskan anjing tersepit.
Second Example Sentence: Sudah dijangka—dia membalas budi dengan tuba.
Third Example Sentence: Bantuan itu tidak dihargai, malah memudaratkan—bagai melepaskan anjing tersepit.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Someone who follows others without question
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from how buffaloes are led by piercing their noses
First Example Sentence: Jangan jadi bagai kerbau dicucuk hidung—fikir dulu sebelum ikut.
Second Example Sentence: Dia ikut arahan tanpa soal, macam kerbau dicucuk hidung.
Third Example Sentence: Pemuda itu, bagai kerbau dicucuk hidung, percaya bulat-bulat.
